prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Disk structure - Bright disks
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 7 observations in continuum and 12CO(3-2) line, with a resolution 1.08" (C34-1 configuration). These observations will constrain disk masses and structure in combination with SG3, and we will also detect the 12CO(3-2) line. This SG is optimized for the brigthest disks in the sample.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Combining Band 7 870 microns imaging with 1.3mm data (SG3), we will be able to study the disk emission vs wavelength and vs disk size, constraining the dust grain sizes and disk structure by exploring the dust opacity changes with radius. With Band 7, we will also take advantage to trace the 12CO(3-2) line to constrain the presence of gas in the disks. Our main constrain is sensitivity, given that the objects are faint, so we request the C34-1 configuration. Since the cluster is at 138pc, we do not require a very high spatial resolution to already answer the question of the extent of the disk (all disks are expected to have diameters well over 1"). Dust continuum emission has been estimated from SED modeling, including data from optical to far-IR wavelengths (Herschel/PACS) using the radiative transfer code RADMC (Dullemond & Dominik 2004). All RADMC models are published in Sicilia-Aguilar et al. (2013), an example with CASA simulation is shown in Fig. 2. Given the SED degeneracy, we estimate the ALMA fluxes considering the worst-case-scenario models (100 AU disks, grain growth up to 100um only) to ensure detection. Gas emission is estimated from existing observations of Taurus objects, scaling with the continuum flux (Thi et al. 2001, Guilloteau et al. 2013). The 870 micron wavelength is specially sensitive to changes in dust distribution and structure, being a key parameter to break the degeneracy of the models as shown in Fig. 2 of the scientific justification, once the far-IR fluxes have been constrained (with Herschel) and in combination with a dust mass determination obtained with the 1.3mm observations. The 12CO(3-2) gas line is optically thick, but it can set up a lower limit to the disk mass. The ratio of the two CO transitions will constrain the gas temperature, which together with the spatial resolution of gas emission can be used to compare the gas and dust distributions. The requested velocity resolution of 0.2 km/s will enable us to separate different components (e.g. disk motions, outflows) and also cloud emission (although the objects are located in clean parts of the cluster, see Fig2, Sicilia-Aguilar et al. 2013, and Harju et al. 1993, so we do not expect much contamination).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Disk structure - Faint disks
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 7 observations in continuum and 12CO(3-2) line, with a resolution about 1.08" (C34-1 configuration). Similar to SG1, but optimized for the faintest disks in the sample.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: SG2 is similar to SG1 but optimized for the faint targets. In the case of the faint disks in our sample, sensitivity is an issue at longer wavelengths, and the flux from Band 7 at 870 micron already depends strongly on the physical mechanism responsible for their low Herschel fluxes (e.g. truncation vs dust depletion vs gaps). Because of this, we will use deep band 7 only observations to check the disk size and mass as well as the presence of gas. Note that even the moderate 1.08" resolution will enable us to constrain whether disks are truncated to radii below ~75AU, significantly different from typical disk sizes (100-300 AU). Note that the flux of G-1 is significantly lower than that of the other two targets, since the estimated worst-case model mass of G-1 is nearly 2 orders of magnitude lower. Therefore, even though the SNR for this Science Goal appears very low due to this one object, CrA-159 and HBC-677 should be easily detected, and G-1 will also be detected unless it is strongly mass-depleted or truncated, which would be a very interesting result on its own. Dust continuum emission has been estimated from SED modeling (RADMC, see models published in Sicilia-Aguilar et al. 2013). Gas emission is estimated from existing observations of Taurus objects, scaling with the continuum flux (Thi et al. 2001, Guilloteau et al. 2013). The 870 micron wavelength is specially sensitive to changes in dust distribution and structure, once the far-IR fluxes have been constrained (with Herschel). The 12CO(3-2) gas line is optically thick, but it can set up a lower limit to the disk mass, which is specially important in these disks that show very low far-IR dust emission. HBC-677 and CrA-159 show ongoing accretion, so gas detection at levels comparable to Taurus similar Taurus disks is expected. For G-1, which shows a remarkably flattened and/or dust depleted disk and no evidence of ongoing accretion, gas detection may be compromised if the disk is truly depleted, but a strong upper limit is essential to constrain the mechanisms responsible for the low mass and fast evolution of this object. Conversely, a strong gas detection in G-1 would be a proof that only the dust contain of the disk is affected (as in the case of strong grain growth or dust removal or filtering). Note that, as in SG1, the objects are located in clean environments where cloud contamination is not expected.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Mass estimates for bright disks
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band 6 observations aimed at determining the disk dust masses and gaseous content as well as the size of the disk in gas and dust. This science goal contains the brightest disks in the sample.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We will use Band 6 observations with configuration C34-2 to determine the continuum flux at 1.3mm and observe the 12CO(2-1) transition, which can be translated into disk sizes, disk dust masses, and approximate gas masses. Combined with Band 7 observations (SG1), we can also constain the dust distribution and disk structure. The continuum fluxes are estimated by SED fitting using the radiative transfer code RADMC (Dullemond & Dominik 2004) and taking into account our multi-wavelength data (from optical to Herschel/PACS data, see models published in Sicilia-Aguilar et al. 2013). Since the SEDs are highly degenerated (Sicilia-Aguilar et al. 2013), we consider the worst-case-scenario models to ensure detectability (maximum growth size 100 microns, disk size 100 AU), so the fluxes listed are expected to be lower limits. The line fluxes in 12CO(2-1) are estimated assuming the observed relation between line and continuum for early M-type Taurus stars and their typical line widths (Thi et al. 2001, Guilloteau et al. 2013) The spatial resolution of 0.89" is enough to reveal approximate outer disk sizes and structures for typical disks (radii 100-300 AU) located at 138pc. The velocity resolution in the 12CO(2-1) line is set to 0.16 km/s, to disentangle potential different disk and outflow components and cloud emission (although all sources are located in clean environments, Sicilia-Aguilar et al. 2013, Harju et al. 1993). Even though the CO line is optically thick and can be also affected by freezing onto the grains, it will be used to check the presence of gas in the disk and the extent of gaseous emission compared to the dusty counterpart, and can also provide a lower limit to the gas mass and information on its temperature (combined with 12CO(3-2) in SG1).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Protoplanetary disks follow different evolutionary paths from early on. Studying how the disk dispersal mechanisms depend on initial conditions requires fixing age, stellar mass/luminosity, and cluster environment, and breaking the degeneracy of unresolved SED observations. To connect evolutionary paths, dispersal mechanisms, and initial conditions, we will use ALMA and a sample of homogeneous, well-known, young, coeval disks around similar-mass stars: the early-M stars in the young (<1-2 Myr), nearby (138 pc) and coeval Coronet cluster. We will use bands 6 and 7 to measure the dust continuum, CO emission, and disk (dust and gas) radii and masses of the 7 disks around M0-M2 stars, with resolution 1.1-0.89" (~150-120AU). Our Spitzer and Herschel data revealed different inner disk structures and evolutionary paths, from inside-out evolution (inner holes/gaps), to very low dust masses. With 6.34h of ALMA time we can break the degeneracy of disk structures (and thus physical processes) in the unresolved SEDs, exploring the connection between disk dispersal mechanisms and global disk properties, which can be traced back to initial conditions and angular momentum in the collapsing cores.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: The proposal is a resubmission, with scientific and technical improvements, of proposal 2012.1.00308.S. All the issues raised in the previous cycle have been addressed in the new version.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
